Body:
I just found out, that with respect to the German language, where prefixes of verbs are separated from the verb and posed behind the object, I have no chance to find out, if a verb with a prefix is used more frequent than than the same verb without the prefix.

Eg.

Er schätz sie.

and

Er schätzt sie ab.

Note in the latter case the infinitive form of the verb is 'abschätzen'.

Edit:

cf. http://books.google.com/ngrams/info
Title: Are there tools similar Google ngram, which recognise conjugated or declined word forms?

LastEditedUser.AboutMe:
Travelling armchair linguist.

Never studied in an institution but read books and web with probably more breadth than depth.

Always on the road surviving in a strange foreign language, currently Mongolian and Mandarin Chinese.

And I collect dictionaries.

OwnerUser.AboutMe:
Database developer for SQL-Server and ORACLE. Doing a lot with PowerShell.

I'm German and it is now only 4 years that I started bloging (in english) and now i'm contibuting to several OpenSource Projects. Codeplex SQLPSX is the most important of them.
